awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Examining Pyrotechnology and Ecosystem Change in the Archaeological Record
awd_abstract_narration:
Knowing when humans began using fire allows us to better understand our evolutionary and biological history. This project will explore the question of early fire use through archaeological investigation of human activities from 1 to 2 million years ago. The investigators will use ancient archaeological and environmental data, along with modern data, to simulate how human exposure to landscape fire would influence behavior and how human use of fire would have affected landscapes. This research will provide insights into human relationships with fire and help clarify the extent to which fire was a catalyst for human cultural and biological development. The project will support early career researchers, efforts to broaden participation in paleoanthropology, and research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. The research will be used to develop an educational outreach program with the American Museum of Natural History that is focused on increasing scientific participation of economically and educationally diverse middle and high school students.

Archaeological excavation and sampling will be used to identify fire 1 to 2 million years ago in a region with a vast fossil and archaeological record that spans between 4 and 1 million years ago. The investigators will study burning of organic matter using polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, plant waxes, infrared spectroscopy of bone and sediment, identification of microscopic charcoal, and microscopic plant fossils. They will investigate these proxies at archaeological sites, in fossil soils, and a sediment core from a body of water that borders the research area. Investigations of these patterns at small scales (within archaeological sites) and at local to regional ecosystem levels (paleosols and sediment core) will be used to develop agent-based models of ecosystem responses to human fire use and generate predictions about the frequency and origin of landscape fires. This project combines experimental and archaeological advances with targeted field studies to address these questions and provide insights into this critical adaptation in human technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report for Collaborative Research: Examining Pyrotechnology and Ecosystem Change in the Archaeological Record

Award NSF BCS 2413996

This project investigated fire ecology and the potential timing and nature of fire use in early humans, focusing on the detection and analysis of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) as biomarkers of fire use. The research was focused in the Turkana Basin region of norther Kenya, where there is an exceptional record of hominin fossils, archeological sites, and paleoecological records aimed at understanding the evolution, behavior, and habitats of early humans.

The research team from Harvard focused on the use of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) analysis to identify ancient fire. PAHs, complex organic molecules produced during the burning of biomass, provide a reliable chemical signature of fire, even when other physical evidence, such as charcoal, is absent. By comparing sediment samples from archaeological sites with those from non-archaeological contexts, we found evidence for significantly higher PAH concentrations at sites associated with human activity, particularly around 1.5 million years ago, well after the emergence of Homo erectus. These findings support the hypothesis that early hominins interacted with and perhaps controlled fire for various purposes, including cooking and habitat management.

The PAH analyses included distinguishing between pyrogenic (fire-related) and petrogenic (fossil fuel-related) sourced forms. This allowed for the assessment of the preservation state of PAHs to ensure accurate interpretations of the archaeological record. Elevated pyrogenic PAH levels provided compelling evidence for localized and repeated fire use by early humans at one site in east Turkana in the Koobi Fora Formation, suggesting a significant behavioral adaptation occurred ~1.5 million years ago. 

To contextualize these findings and integrate them into a broader analytical framework, the project linked PAH data with other fire proxies, such as soil micromorphology, Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy of burned bones, burned phytoliths, thermally-altered lithic materials (stones), and magnetic anomalies in soils, which were examined across archaeological sites and surrounding landscapes. Agent-based modeling further illustrated how human-controlled fires could influence the distribution of charcoal and PAH signals over time and space, providing a farmwork for differentiating anthropogenic fire regimes from natural ones. We also leveraged long-term regional records from sediment cores extracted from Lake Turkana. These cores provide a continuous archive of fire incidence and ecological change, showing correlations between PAH concentrations, climate fluctuations, and vegetation patterns. 

Beyond its scientific contributions, the project emphasized outreach and education by offering research internships to high school students and undergraduates as well as independent research opportunities for graduate students and postdocs. We established a tiered mentoring systems for research interns, several of whom presented their research results are conferences.  More broadly, the project collaborated with local communities in Kenya to foster scientific literacy.

This research advanced our understanding of the origins and significance of fire in human history. By uncovering the chemical traces of ancient fires from PAHs across local and regional scales and integrating these results with a wide range of other proxies, the project made advances toward understanding when pyrotechnology started to shaped the evolutionary trajectory of Homo erectus and perhaps other Pleistocene hominins.
